text: The moment the customer felt compelled enough to go out of their way to talk about some problem, that's a unbelievable gift. I will leave a meeting to just get one message back to them. If you're text message friendly with five or 10 of those, you are going to have so much direct signal that is infectious.
speaker: Jeff Weinstein
context: Lenny is discussing Jeff's unique approach to customer engagement on Twitter. Jeff explains his philosophy about responding to customer feedback with extreme urgency and building direct relationships with customers. He emphasizes that when customers take time from their busy lives to communicate about your product, it represents an incredible opportunity that should be treated with the highest priority.
text_ko: 고객이 굳이 시간을 내서 어떤 문제에 대해 얘기할 만큼 마음이 동했다는 순간은 정말 믿기 힘든 선물이에요. 저는 그 한 통의 메시지를 전하려고 회의를 나가기도 해요. 그런 고객 다섯, 열 명과 문자(text message)로 편하게 지내면 직접적인 신호(direct signal)가 엄청나게 쌓이고, 그 신호들이 전염성 있게 퍼져요.
text_zh: 客户主动找上门来跟你聊他们遇到的问题，这简直是天大的礼物啊。碰到这种情况，我开会都能停下来，就为了马上回复他们一条消息。如果你能跟五到十个这样的客户保持微信联系，那你得到的第一手反馈(direct signal)就太有价值了，而且这种影响力会传染的。
text_es: En el momento en que el cliente se siente tan motivado que se toma la molestia de hablarte sobre algún problema, eso es un regalo increíble. Yo dejo una reunión solo para responderle un mensaje. Si tienes esa confianza por WhatsApp o mensaje con cinco o diez de esos clientes, vas a tener una información directa (direct signal) tan valiosa que es contagiosa.

text: We show up four to eight people total pretend to be some company with some outcome problem. Rule one is you do not work at Stripe and rule two is we're not here to solve any problems. This is just about practicing empathy for the customer.
speaker: Jeff Weinstein
context: Lenny asks Jeff about study groups, a program he started at Stripe. Jeff explains how study groups work - they're sessions where Stripe employees roleplay as customers using their own products. Study groups are designed to help teams understand the customer experience by forcing employees to abandon their internal knowledge and approach products with fresh eyes, purely to build empathy rather than to critique or fix issues.
text_ko: 총 4~8명이 모여 어떤 회사를 가장하고 그 회사가 성과 문제(outcome problem)를 겪는 상황을 연기해요. 규칙 하나는 Stripe 직원이 아니어야 해요. 규칙 둘은 여기서 실제 문제를 해결하려고 온 게 아니에요. 이건 단지 고객에 대한 공감을 연습하는 자리예요.
text_zh: 我们会派四到八个人，假装是某个公司遇到了什么问题。第一条规则是你不能说自己在Stripe工作，第二条规则是我们不是来解决问题的。这个练习就是为了培养对客户的同理心。
text_es: Llegamos entre cuatro y ocho personas en total y fingimos ser una empresa con algún problema o resultado que necesitamos. La regla número uno es que no trabajas en Stripe y la regla número dos es que no estamos aquí para resolver ningún problema. Esto es solo para practicar la empatía con el cliente.

text: Some of it was just the fact that I wasn't particularly good at the class and had to rationalize it for myself in some form. So in retrospect that sounds highfalutin, but at the time I just wasn't particularly good at the classes I was in.
speaker: Jeff Weinstein
context: Lenny asks Jeff about a quote where he chose to stay in classes he was potentially the worst at rather than dropping to easier levels. Jeff explains his unconventional academic approach and how his liberal arts education shaped his thinking. He's reflecting on how his willingness to stay in challenging situations, even when struggling, came from both necessity and a philosophical approach to learning that he developed in school.
text_ko: 사실 일부는 제가 그 수업을 특별히 잘하지 못해서였고, 그래서 제 나름대로 어떻게든 합리화했어요. 지금 돌이켜 보면 거창하게 들릴 수 있지만, 당시에는 그냥 제가 들었던 수업들을 잘 못했던 것뿐이에요.
text_zh: 有一部分原因说白了就是我在那门课上表现不怎么样，得给自己找个台阶下。现在回头看这话听起来挺装的，但当时我确实就是在上的那些课里表现平平。
text_es: Parte de eso era simplemente que no se me daba muy bien esa materia y tenía que justificármelo de alguna manera. Ahora en retrospectiva suena muy rebuscado, pero en ese momento simplemente no era muy bueno en las clases que estaba tomando.

text: So I see the world as immediately we have just such opportunity to take action in front of us. We can be optimistic and go, go, go as soon as possible. I think that a lot of life is you get as much furniture as you've room in the house. We will do the work the night before it's due, so let's just make it due tomorrow.
speaker: Jeff Weinstein
context: Lenny asks Jeff to explain his philosophy of 'go, go, go ASAP plus optimistic, long-term compounding approach.' Jeff describes his belief in taking immediate action while maintaining optimism. He uses metaphors to explain how artificial urgency can drive productivity - comparing it to how work expands to fill available time, and suggesting that creating tighter deadlines can accelerate progress and create momentum.
vocabulary_highlights: take action in front of us
as much furniture as you've room in the house
text_ko: 저는 세상을 보면 바로 눈앞에 행동할 기회가 있다고 봐요. 낙관적으로 가능한 한 빨리 시작해서 계속 밀고 나가면 돼요. 인생의 많은 부분은 집에 들어갈 만큼 가구를 채워 넣는 것처럼, 가능한 만큼 이것저것 채워 넣는 거라고 생각해요. 우리는 다들 마감 전날 밤에 일을 하는 편이니까, 그러니 마감일을 그냥 내일로 정해버리자고요.
text_zh: 所以我觉得现在机会就摆在我们面前，我们应该保持乐观，马上行动起来。我觉得人生就是这样，你有多大房子就放多少家具。反正活儿都是截止前一晚才做完，那不如把截止时间定在明天。
text_es: Mira, yo veo que el mundo ahora mismo nos está poniendo oportunidades increíbles justo enfrente. Podemos ser optimistas y echarle ganas, arrancar ya mismo. Creo que en la vida pasa mucho eso de que uno llena la casa con todos los muebles que le caben. Siempre terminamos haciendo el trabajo la noche anterior a la entrega, entonces mejor pongamos la fecha límite para mañana.

text: I think I'm really working backwards from failures in the past and avoiding them. And so maybe just a quick story. I started a company several years ago based on just a personal pet peeve of mine, which was I was a SQL analyst.
speaker: Jeff Weinstein
context: Lenny asks Jeff why craft and quality are so important to him in product development. Jeff explains that his obsession with craft comes from learning from past mistakes. He's about to share a story about a company he started that taught him important lessons about the difference between building something people like versus building something people truly need and will pay for.
text_ko: 저는 과거의 실패들을 되돌아보며 거기서부터 역으로 접근해서 같은 실수를 피하려고 하는 것 같아요. 간단한 얘기 하나만 할게요. 몇 년 전에 제가 SQL 분석가(SQL analyst)로 일하면서 느꼈던 개인적인 불편함 때문에 회사를 하나 시작했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得我其实是在从过去的失败中吸取教训，然后尽量避免重蹈覆辙。简单讲个故事吧。几年前我创办了一家公司，完全是因为我个人的一个痛点，当时我是做SQL分析的。
text_es: Creo que realmente estoy trabajando al revés, partiendo de los fracasos del pasado para evitarlos. Te cuento rápido una historia. Hace varios años monté una empresa basándome en algo que me molestaba muchísimo a nivel personal, y es que yo era analista de SQL.

text: People don't really get out of bed for their second problem. They get out of bed for their first problem. And you have to carefully listen and not pitch your customer or your prospective customer as you're trying to figure this out.
speaker: Jeff Weinstein
context: Jeff is explaining why product craft must come after solving a real customer problem. He emphasizes the importance of identifying customers' most urgent, burning problems rather than secondary issues. Jeff is teaching a methodology for customer discovery that focuses on listening rather than pitching, arguing that customers will only be truly motivated to act on their most pressing challenges.
text_ko: 사람들은 두 번째 문제 때문에 굳이 일어나지 않아요. 첫 번째 문제 때문에 일어나요. 이걸 알아내려면 고객이나 잠재 고객(prospective customer)에게 조심스럽게 귀 기울이고, 알아내는 동안 바로 피치(pitch)하려 들지 말아야 해요.
text_zh: 其实人们起床后首先想到的不是第二重要的问题，而是最迫切需要解决的那个问题。所以你得仔细听客户怎么说，在摸清楚这一点的时候千万别急着推销，不管是现有客户还是潜在客户都一样。
text_es: La gente no se levanta de la cama por su segundo problema. Se levanta por el primero. Y tienes que escuchar con mucha atención y no estar vendiendo a tu cliente o prospecto mientras tratas de entender esto.

text: If you've earned trust along the way, and certainly not pitching is a great way of earning trust. You're just listening. We've learned a lot at Stripe from that. And that's where you can start to find adjacencies, right?
speaker: Jeff Weinstein
context: Jeff is continuing his explanation of how to discover customer problems through listening rather than pitching. He's describing how this approach builds trust with customers and can reveal new product opportunities. Jeff explains how at Stripe, they discovered adjacencies - related business opportunities - by listening to customers describe problems that weren't directly related to Stripe's core payment processing business.
text_ko: 그동안 신뢰를 쌓아왔다면, 확실히 피칭(pitching)을 하지 않는 게 신뢰를 얻는 좋은 방법이에요. 그저 상대 얘기를 들어주는 거죠. 스트라이프에서도 그걸 통해 많은 걸 배웠어요. 바로 그 지점에서 인접 영역(adjacencies)을 찾아보기 시작할 수 있어요, 그렇죠?
text_zh: 如果你在这个过程中赢得了信任，不推销反而是建立信任的好方法。你就是在倾听。我们在Stripe学到了很多这样的经验。这样你就能开始找到相关的机会点，对吧？
text_es: Si has ganado confianza en el proceso, y desde luego no hacer pitch todo el tiempo es una excelente manera de ganar esa confianza. Simplemente escuchas. En Stripe hemos aprendido muchísimo de eso. Y ahí es donde puedes empezar a encontrar oportunidades adyacentes, ¿no?
